moves.2... Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. d3 e6 5. Bg5 Be7: In my opinion, it would have been much better for my opponent to take on d5. It appears he didn't have a plan, since he had pretty much forced my knight to move to d5 after playing e5.
moves.9... Nxf4 10. Nxf4 Nxe5: With the white bishop gone, I win a pawn.
moves.11. d4 cxd4 12. Qxd4: I always get nervous when my opponent's queen gets out in the open.
moves.12... Bh4+: I play this move in hopes that my opponent will play g3, but it is a bad habbit to hope.
moves.13. Ke2 Nc6 14. Qc3: It would have saved white a move if he had not moved there.
moves.14... Bf6 15. Qe3 d5 16. Nh5 Be7 17. Nd4: Now I must be careful of the white queen coming to the a1-h8 diagonal, threatening mate.
moves.17... Bd6 18. Nxc6 bxc6 19. Qd4 e5: This was the move I prepared with 17...Bd6. My light square bishop is now free.
moves.20. Qf2 e4: I was prepared to bring my rook to e8 either after fxe5 or after I pushed it further. After 21...e3, neither queen nor king can take safely on e3 due to Re8 and Be5, respectively.
moves.21. Qd4 Qg5 22. Qxg7+: In a huge miscalculation, my opponent took on g7.
Now my bishop pair dominates the board, and as you will see, together they prove unstoppable.
moves.30. Rc6 Re6 31. Rc7: A huge blunder. The bishop is almost too far away from the action to be seen.
moves.31... Bxc7 32. g3: Note that if Bxg3, Rg1 ensues.
moves.32... Bb7 33. Be2 Rd8 34. f4 d3: There's no stopping my passed pawns as they are supported by the rooks and eachother.
moves.35. Bg4 Re7 36. Rh1: Deja Vu: My bishop watches from afar.
moves.37... f6 38. Kc1 e2 39. Kd2 Ba5+ 40. Kc1: At this point I called checkmate, and my opponent agreed, that is until my teamates saw otherwise.
moves.41. Bd1 Rc8+ 42. Kb1 Qxd1#: A great finish to my first game of the 2009/2010 season. I felt good. Rating and commenting are appreciated.
